Expectation1: Adhere to site protocols and work effectively as part of the team.
Situation1: The mandatory daily pre-work safety briefing is starting in two minutes.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I wipe the sweat from my brow as I glance at my watch—6:58 a.m. The foreman’s voice echoes across the site, calling everyone to the daily safety briefing. I know the rules: if I’m late, I’ll get written up, maybe even sent home. My crew depends on me, and I can’t let them down. But I’m standing in the school gym, ballot envelope in hand, as the poll worker frowns and points to a smudge on my signature. “I’m sorry, sir, but you’ll need to re-sign this so your vote counts,” she says. I nod, but my hands are shaking. If I leave now, I’ll miss my chance to fix the ballot. If I stay, I’ll be late for the briefing. Both sides are counting on me—my team for a safe, productive day, and my community for a fair election. My heart pounds as I stare at the pen, torn between duty to my job and my right to vote, knowing I can’t be in two places at once.
